results.title: Kip and David. Episode 05
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Kip and David”.
David and his elfin friend work together on Kip’s tree house, using a framework of branches, thatching it with banana leaves and leaving spaces for a doorway and window. Finally, they build a rock garden, and place ‘Kip’s House’ above the entrance. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 02
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Kip and David”.
Kip, the bushland elf, and David explore their holiday island and find a huge Aboriginal midden-heap of bleached white shells. They then move onto the beach and rock pools looking for shellfish and crabs. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 01
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Kip and David”.
David, a young boy, goes by boat to Stradbroke Island on a holiday. As he collects Banksia cones in the bush, he hears honey-eaters followed by piping music played by a friendly elf. Together they explore the caves along the coast. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.

results.title: Kip and David
results.creator_credit: Arthur Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: A thirteen part children’s adventure series made by Arthur and Corinne Cantrill about a young boy called David who meets a bushland elf while holidaying on Queensland’s Stradbroke Island and embarks on a series of adventures that highlight Australia’s wildlife and natural surroundings.

results.title: Kinship and descent. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Coast Community College District, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In many societies, kinship helps to structure the behaviour of an individual. Because most societies organise themselves around kinship lines, anthropologists study these lines in great detail when studying a particular group of people. Covers the matrilineal society of Navaho Indians of North America, the “Yanamamo” people of South America (patrilineal) and the Kipseli village on Thera island in Greece. Narrated By David Carradine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Coast Community College District, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner

Narrated By David Carradine.

results.title: Kinship and descent. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Coast Community College District, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In many societies kinship and descent help serve the political, economic and religious functions that make societies work as a whole. This program covers tribesmen of Papua New Guinea who trace their descent back so far beyond human memory, that clans are descended from mythical ancestors. Compares patrilineal and matrilineal societies and shows how kinship and descent can solve problems of succession, inheritance and social order. Also contrasts modern western society. Narrated by David Carradine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Coast Community College District, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner

Compares patrilineal and matrilineal societies and shows how kinship and descent can solve problems of succession, inheritance and social order. Also contrasts modern western society. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Kinora
results.credit_line: Lent by the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Sydney. Purchased 1963.
results.brief_description: In 1896, the Lumière brothers came up with the Kinora, a smaller cinematic device that worked like a mutoscope and flickered through 40-second stories.

results.title: Kings row
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, William Cameron Menzies and Sam Wood
results.brief_description: Kings Row was well ahead of its time, anticipating fifties melodramas such as “Peyton Place” and those of Sirk, Minnelli et al., in its subversive view of small town America. The scriptwriter Casey Robinson takes most of the credit for managing to win the approval of Production Code officials during the repressive Breen and post-Breen years. Incest in the novel is thinly disguised in the film as hereditary insanity. Leg amputation is virtually synonymous with castration. The American doctor-fathers are middle class monsters while positive values are inverted almost exclusively in European immigrants and the working class. Religion rates no mention in a world clearly polarised between good and evil. The young people’s struggle to overcome obstacles is heightened to the point of self parody as melodrama of triumph. Visual design was mainly the work of William Cameron Menzies (who storyboarded the whole film) and cinematographer James Wong Howe. From the novel by Henry Bellamann. Cast includes: Ann Sheridan, Robert Cummings, Ronald Reagan, Betty Field, Charles Coburn.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Warner Bros Pictures, William Cameron Menzies and Sam Wood
results.description: Kings Row was well ahead of its time, anticipating fifties melodramas such as “Peyton Place” and those of Sirk, Minnelli et al., in its subversive view of small town America. The scriptwriter Casey Robinson takes most of the credit for managing to win the approval of Production Code officials during the repressive Breen and post-Breen years. Incest in the novel is thinly disguised in the film as hereditary insanity. Leg amputation is virtually synonymous with castration. The American doctor-fathers are middle class monsters while positive values are inverted almost exclusively in European immigrants and the working class. Religion rates no mention in a world clearly polarised between good and evil. The young people’s struggle to overcome obstacles is heightened to the point of self parody as melodrama of triumph. Visual design was mainly the work of William Cameron Menzies (who storyboarded the whole film) and cinematographer James Wong Howe. From the novel by Henry Bellamann. Cast includes: Ann Sheridan, Robert Cummings, Ronald Reagan, Betty Field, Charles Coburn.

results.title: Kings of sport
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and Arthur C. Stevens
results.brief_description: Introducing twenty five years of sporting champions, including; Henry Seagrove on land and water; Donald Campbell’s land speed record; John Cobb; TT Races on the Isle of Man; Fred Perry at Wimbledon; Henry Cotton the golfer; Denis Compton and Donald Bradman at cricket.
